subject: Running multiple test cases in JUnit (question about JUnit design)

messageBody:
What's the rational behind creating test suite out of test methods,
and not test classes? JUnit instantiates new object of TestCase for
every method (when TestSuite.addTestCase(Â…) is called), which results
in a) a lot of objects being newed, and b) setUp() and tearDown()
methods called every time test method is invoked. During my work with
API testing I notices that a) it is more modular to write one test
class per one tested class, where test class includes multiple test
methods; In this case I need to instantiate app container (which
would be set up) only once, before I start running multiple test
classes. Objects created in "set up" are shared by test classes, and
don't need to be created every time test method is called. I
understand that decision to instantiate TestClass for every test
method was stipulated by some rational of design, I am trying to
understand what this rational is?
